section.title: Finding Speakers
section.para: Finding speakers is extremely easy if you know where to look. The easiest place to go for speakers is definitely the staff. There are a lot of professors and researchers doing interesting things that wouldn't mind sharing their work. Graduate students will also jump at the chance to present their work in preparation for their thesis defence.
Here's a simple email you could send to mailing lists:

example.title: Example Email to Mailing List
example.para:
Greetings,
ACM is looking for speakers for the current Spring, and upcoming Fall, semester. Any technical topic is acceptable -- even research, senior design project presentations, or an interesting topic/project you'd like to share with the club. Please forward your suggestions to me regarding topics or potential speakers.
We look forward to seeing you at the meetings.

section.para: If no one speaks up then it's time to go the club and see if any members would be willing to speak.
Lastly, remember that no fish is too big. We've gotten big deal speakers just by sending them a direct email. Like Corey Haines and Richard Stallman.

section.title: Coordinating With Speakers
section.para: You can't communicate too much with a speaker, especially if they're travelling from out of town to come see us. Make sure they have all of the information they need.

If the speaker is flying in, make sure that all of their expenses are handled with WVU (speak to the chair first to make the deparartment will pay of course). Ensure the speaker has a ride around town and arrives at the event with some time to spare.
It's also good to walk the speaker around and introduce them to the faculty that may be in that day.
Also, know when to give the speaker some space as well if you're going to be around them a lot. This was the case with Corey Haines. We basically asked him when he needed some alone time, etc.

section.title: Food
section.para: When ordering food for any sort of event, make sure to include a vegetarian option!

listitem.para: Event room is booked with the University.
A post about the event has been posted on wvu.acm.org
All mailing lists have been notified about the event.
In the case of a larger event, press has been notified.
Speaker will have access to a computer/laptop/projector in the event room.
